channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: As Kenya's flood toll rises, Human Rights Watch says officials must step up efforts
item.description: Human Rights Watch accuses Kenyan authorities of not responding adequately to ongoing floods that have killed more than 170 people since the start of the rainy season.
item.content:encoded:
Human Rights Watch accuses Kenyan authorities of not responding adequately to ongoing floods that have killed more than 170 people since the start of the rainy season.

(Image credit: Andre Kasuku)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Indiana will have its first competitive primary election in two decades
item.description: Indiana has its first competitive primary for governor in two decades, as six Republicans vie for their party's nomination. Current Governor Eric Holcomb is term-limited after eight years in office.
item.content:encoded:
Indiana has its first competitive primary for governor in two decades, as six Republicans vie for their party's nomination. Current Governor Eric Holcomb is term-limited after eight years in office.

(Image credit: Brandon Smith)
item.dc:creator: Brandon Smith

item.title: FTC bars former Pioneer CEO in Exxon Mobil deal, saying he colluded with OPEC
item.description: Exxon Mobil's $60 billion deal to buy Pioneer Natural Resources received federal clearance, but former Pioneer CEO Scott Sheffield was barred from joining the new company's board of directors.
item.content:encoded:
Exxon Mobil's $60 billion deal to buy Pioneer Natural Resources received federal clearance, but former Pioneer CEO Scott Sheffield was barred from joining the new company's board of directors.

(Image credit: Jacob Ford)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: What Does Winning Look Like for Ukraine Now?
item.description: After months of delay in Congress, Ukraine is finally receiving the U.S. military aid it says is crucial in winning its fight against Russia. But after two years of war, what it means to win is increasingly complicated. We hear about the state of the conflict from our correspondent in Kyiv and our Pentagon correspondent.
item.content:encoded: After months of delay in Congress, Ukraine is finally receiving the U.S. military aid it says is crucial in winning its fight against Russia. But after two years of war, what it means to win is increasingly complicated. We hear about the state of the conflict from our correspondent in Kyiv and our Pentagon correspondent.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: Why does TB have such a hold on the Inuit communities of the Canadian Arctic?
item.description: Canada has one of the world's lowest rates of tuberculosis. Yet this deadly disease is surging among Indigenous people in this icy, remote part of the country.
item.content:encoded:
Canada has one of the world's lowest rates of tuberculosis. Yet this deadly disease is surging among Indigenous people in this icy, remote part of the country.

(Image credit: Richard McManus)
item.dc:creator: Melody Schreiber

item.title: Whistleblower Joshua Dean, who raised concerns about Boeing jets, dies at 45
item.description: Dean's family says he quickly fell into critical condition after being diagnosed with a MRSA bacterial infection. He is the second aviation whistleblower to die in the past three months.
item.content:encoded:
Dean's family says he quickly fell into critical condition after being diagnosed with a MRSA bacterial infection. He is the second aviation whistleblower to die in the past three months.

(Image credit: Jason Redmond)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Why are so many government officials concerned about TikTok?
item.description: Congress and President Biden say TikTok must shed its financial ties to China or face a ban in the U.S. But Washington Post tech reporter Drew Harwell says selling the company is complicated.
item.content:encoded: Congress and President Biden say TikTok must shed its financial ties to China or face a ban in the U.S. But Washington Post tech reporter Drew Harwell says selling the company is complicated.

item.title: Peloton is laying off workers and replacing the CEO — again
item.description: It's déjà vu for the luxury fitness company: Peloton is cutting about 400 more jobs, and its CEO is stepping down just two years after a major shakeup.
item.content:encoded:
It's déjà vu for the luxury fitness company: Peloton is cutting about 400 more jobs, and its CEO is stepping down just two years after a major shakeup.

(Image credit: Ezra Shaw)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Biden says he supports the right to protest but denounces 'chaos' and hate speech
item.description: President Biden had an unexpected update to his schedule Thursday to address the pro-Palestinian protests roiling campuses across the country.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden had an unexpected update to his schedule Thursday to address the pro-Palestinian protests roiling campuses across the country.

(Image credit: Evan Vucci)
item.dc:creator: NPR Washington Desk

item.title: The U.S. may be missing human cases of bird flu, scientists say
item.description: Officially, only one person has caught the illness during the current outbreak. But with limited testing, cases could be flying under the radar.
item.content:encoded:
Officially, only one person has caught the illness during the current outbreak. But with limited testing, cases could be flying under the radar.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Will Stone
